content: Distribute a news release with PR

html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font blockquote i span
content: Note: Links were good at the time we posted this column, but they often go bad after a while. We make no guarantees.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font i span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p b a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "Why do they hate us?" was a common refrain after Sept. 11; far less often heard was the converse question: Why do we hate them? Maybe that's because the answer is so obvious, but even so, a reminder every now and then doesn't do any harm. A group of radical Islamists in London are providing just such a reminder, holding a rally to celebrate--yes, celebrate--the atrocities their coreligionists committed a year ago. The poster nearby advertises the event with the slogan "September the 11th 2001: A towering day in history." Oh, those wacky Islamic punsters.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "The conference, which will be attended by the most radical mullahs in Britain, will argue that the atrocities were justified because Muslims must defend themselves against armed aggression," the London Daily Telegraph reports.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: , the sponsor, has a program for the confab on its Web site; it includes talks on "The positive outcomes of the 11th September 2001," "The US conspiracy against Islam and Muslims" and "The alliance of the US and Al-Saud [our friends the Saudis] in their attack against Muslims." The men behind the celebration say they're starting a new group called the Islamic Council of Britain, "funded by Saudi-based businessmen, which, if true, will embarrass Saudi Arabia," according to the Telegraph.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: This is of course enraging, but it's also just plain weird. What kind of country, in the midst of a war, allows its mortal enemies to hold a hate-fest on its own soil? It's as if Nazi sympathizers were holding Nuremberg-style rallies in Britain and the U.S. in 1942. In most countries at most times in history, surely the Al-Muhajirounites would be rounded up and arrested, if not executed, for treason.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: One might take a perverse pride that the Anglo-American tradition of freedom is so robust, and so fearless, that it allows even the most thuggish fanatics to speak their minds in public. Or one might argue that this is a case of tolerance gone mad. In any case, let's hope the conference is well attended by folks from

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Maybe the Cold War is a better analogy than World War II. During that conflict, there was a communist fringe in the U.S., and even more so elsewhere in the West, which, McCarthyism notwithstanding, generally was free to express its hatred for America. Everyone remembers how "

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: " Fonda went to North Vietnam in 1972 to show solidarity with the enemy.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Call Scott Ritter "Baghdad Jane." The erstwhile U.N. weapons inspector was in the Iraqi capital yesterday, where he told Iraq's "parliament" as the BBC puts it, "that Iraq is not a threat to the outside world and that military action against the country would not be justifiable." Ritter did call on the Iraqis to let inspectors back in, but he also claimed Iraq has no weapons of mass destruction--though it's hard to see how he could know this, since no inspectors have been to Iraq in four years.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "Iraq could assemble a nuclear weapon in months if it had foreign help," CNN reports, citing a new study by the

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: . "The argument in favor of taking action now, whether it's to compel Baghdad to accept inspectors or to use military force to change the regime, is that it's better to act when [Iraq's] capabilities are still short of reaching their ultimate objective," the report's author, Gary Samore, tells CNN.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: also reports that "Iraq has stepped up its quest for nuclear weapons and has embarked on a worldwide hunt for materials to make an atomic bomb":

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: In the last 14 months, Iraq has sought to buy thousands of specially designed aluminum tubes, which American officials believe were intended as components of centrifuges to enrich uranium. American officials said several efforts to arrange the shipment of the aluminum tubes were blocked or intercepted but declined to say, citing the sensitivity of the intelligence, where they came from or how they were stopped. . . .

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: The attempted purchases are not the only signs of a renewed Iraqi interest in acquiring nuclear arms. President Hussein has met repeatedly in recent months with Iraq's top nuclear scientists and, according to American intelligence, praised their efforts as part of his campaign against the West.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: Iraqi defectors who once worked for the nuclear weapons establishment have told American officials that acquiring nuclear arms is again a top Iraqi priority.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: it says Prime Minister Tony Blair will soon issue on Saddam's efforts to acquire nukes. The

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: reports that "Tony Blair and President George W Bush have agreed to topple Saddam Hussein by military means even if the United Nations does not pass a Security Council resolution authorising the use of force." So much for complaints of U.S. "unilaterialism." Though the U.S. must be

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p i span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: to act alone, there's ample evidence that President Bush is in the midst of assembling an international coalition:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
content: , tells the Associated Press that he agrees with "Washington's position . . . that the United Nation's should play a greater role in resolving the problem with Iraq's alleged nuclear ambitions."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
content: proposed a two-stage plan today that could lead to United Nations authorization of military force against Iraq," the New York Times reports.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
content: 's Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder says he's unalterably opposed to toppling Saddam--but his challenger, Edmund Stoiber, is more flexible, and the election is less than two weeks off.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font ul li span
content: 's Prime Minister Jean Chretien today--though Reuters quotes Chretien's deputy, John Manley, as saying the Canadians "haven't signed on to" Bush's plans for regime change.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Oddly, British and American opponents of overthrowing Saddam (with a few exceptions, such as

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: ) have shied away from forthrightly making the case against intervention, instead professing their ignorance and calling on President Bush to "make the case" against Saddam. The Telegraph's

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: These voices never floundered before. They have never let information alone stand in the way of telling Prime Ministers and Presidents what to do about the Cold War, the Gulf war, the Panama invasion, the Falklands, Global Warming, Poverty, Hunger and Dirt.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: One suspects that they really want to put their collective heads in the sand or, less generously, side with a coalition of anti-Americans, muddled Marxists and confused admirers of Islamism all intent on seeing capitalism, Israel and America crippled. But as this agenda is not quite respectable, so it must be masked by a feigned thirst for knowledge.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: And what about Arab opposition? "Syria is showing increasing signs of unease at Washington's plans to topple Saddam Hussein in neighboring Iraq, fearing it would be the first step in a wave of regime changes in the Middle East to suit US and Israeli interests," the

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: reports. (Such changes, of course, would also suit the interests of the

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p i span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: of the countries whose tyrannical regimes change.) The paper quotes Murhaf Jouejati, a Syrian specialist at Washington's Middle East Institute: "Damascus would not like to see the regime toppled and substituted by a pro-American regime because in that case Damascus would be totally surrounded by American power."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Al-Jazeera seems to think so. "A slip of the tongue by one of Osama bin Laden's top henchmen seems to have betrayed al-Qaeda's most potent secret: its charismatic leader is dead," the Times of London reports. In an interview with the Qatar-based satellite network, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed "referred to bin Laden, who has not been seen since the fall of Afghanistan's Taleban regime, in the past tense. The reporter Yosri Fouda, London bureau chief for al-Jazeera, concluded that bin Laden is now likely to be dead."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Mohammed also told Fouda that, in the Times' words, "the target of the fourth, thwarted hijack attack in Washington was Congress, not the White House; the original plan was to crash aircraft into atomic power stations; and the plotters used simple codes to keep in touch by internet."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: In its report on the al Qaeda confession,

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: declares, believe it or not, that "Washington has accused bin Laden and al Qaeda of being responsible for the attacks."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: , last week Reuters published a photo of the World Trade Center site with the following caption:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: Recovery and debris removal work continues at the site of the World Trade Center known as "ground zero" in New York, March 25, 2002. Human rights around the world have been a casualty of the U.S. "war on terror" since September 11.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: That photo has now disappeared from the Yahoo! archives, and the Washington Post's Howard Kurtz reports that Nancy Bobrowitz, the wire service's spokeswoman, "says the caption was a 'mistake' because the information, drawn from an accompanying story, was taken 'out of context.' " Well, here are the first two paragraphs of the

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: GENEVA (Reuters)--Human rights around the world have been a casualty of the U.S. "war on terror" since September 11.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: In the year since Muslim extremists flew hijacked planes into New York and Washington, killing some 3,000 people, many Western governments have armed themselves with greater powers of arrest and curtailed the legal rights of detainees as they hunt for accomplices.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: The dispatch is headlined "Rights the First Victim of 'War on Terror,' " and only in the third paragraph does reporter Richard Waddington attribute these opinions to "human rights activists"--hardly an unbiased source.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "An Iranian man cut off his seven-year-old daughter's head after suspecting she had been raped by her uncle," Reuters reports, citing a report in an Iranian newspaper. " 'The motive behind the killing was to defend my honor, fame, and dignity,' the paper quoted the father as saying."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Reuters apparently thinks the murder of a seven-year-old girl is kind of cute; the story appears under the heading "Oddly Enough."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "The government mistakenly gave alleged terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui classified documents related to al Qaeda," ABC News reports. "The material--both on disk and as hard copy documents--was sent to Moussaoui as part of discovery for his legal defense, said several legal sources, including one at the Justice Department."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: reports that "German authorities had suspicions nearly two months ago about a Turkish man suspected of plotting to bomb U.S. military bases in Germany, but bureaucratic procedures delayed his arrest until last week":

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: A tip from U.S. security officials that a witness reported the suspect had chemicals at home reached German prosecutors in mid-July, but a judge put off questioning of the woman, scheduled for Aug. 13, because the summons could not be delivered on time, said Elke O'Donoghue, a prosecutor in the city of Stuttgart.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Prosecutors got a search warrant Aug. 30, and six days later they arrested Osman Petmezci and his American fianc√©e, Astrid Eyzaguirre. "Inside the couple's third-floor apartment, police found 287 pounds of bomb-making chemicals--which investigators said Sunday could have been used to make about 44 pounds of gunpowder--along with five pipe bombs, a book about bomb-making and electronic parts apparently intended as detonators." The cops say they don't think the couple were connected with al Qaeda.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
content: Only Outlaws Will Have Suicide Bombs

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is to ask a key meeting of the Palestinian parliament on Monday to outlaw suicide bombing and to reaffirm the Palestinian commitment to peace with Israel," the Associated Press reported. But he ended up doing no such thing. Instead, as the New York Times reports, he "told Palestinian legislators today that he condemned acts of terror against Israeli and Palestinian civilians, and said he believed that peace with Israel was still possible. But he stopped short of calling for an end to all attacks against Israelis."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Even Arafat's condemnation of terror "against Israel civilians" doesn't amount to much, for the Palestinian Arabs don't regard anyone who's ever served in the Israeli Defense Forces (in a country with universal conscription) or who lives in the disputed territories as a "civilian."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: , meanwhile, reports that the IDF found a "powerful bomb" in the offices of what AFP calls "Arafat's mainstream Fatah movement."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Arafat won a Nobel Peace Prize in 1994.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: reports that one of Arafat's cabinet members threatened that, in the paper's words, "the Palestinian Authority might reconsider its recognition of the State of Israel, in view of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's declaration that all the signed agreements between the two sides are canceled." Oh, what a threat! Next thing you know the Palestinians will initiate some sort of hostilities or something.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Here's some good news from the Mideast.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: magazine reports that the terror group Hamas is in ruins. "Israeli intelligence officials tell TIME that since the start last spring of the West Bank offensive known as Operation Defensive Shield, 98% of the members of Hamas' military wing who are known to them in the area have been killed or arrested--a total of 70 men." Who says there's no military solution to terrorism?

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Contrary to early reports, at least one of the men whom U.S. special forces troops shot and killed during an assassination attempt against Afghanistan's President Hamid Karzai was not an assassin. The New York Times reports on how Azimullah Muhammad became "Afghanistan's newest hero":

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: On Friday, television viewers around the world watched BBC reports of a man in a brown tunic watching as an Afghan army guard turned his gun the wrong way -- against President Hamid Karzai and the Kandahar governor, Gul Agha Shirzai.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: "Azimullah didn't hesitate a second, he just jumped on him when he saw him shooting," Khalil Pashtoon, the governor's press secretary, said today of the young man. . . .

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: In the scuffle, the soldier apparently shot the young man as they wrestled to the ground. Then, American Special Forces bodyguards apparently shot them both dead.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
content: Next: O.J. Simpson Lectures Us on Nonviolence

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Former tennis star John McEnroe weighs in with an op-ed in the Daily Telegraph, and we swear we're not making this up:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: In travelling the world as a tennis player, I have a better appreciation of other countries than most Americans. We could do with being a little less besotted with money, money, money, win, win, win. When I am in England each summer people always ask: "Why don't English players win Wimbledon? They ought to be more like Americans and play to win." To my mind, it's time Americans started being more like the English--or at least learnt to lose with grace.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Tom Brazaitis of the Cleveland Plain Dealer reports on an article in Skeptical Inquirer (the piece itself isn't online) that says terrorism is no big deal:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: The authors, research scientists Clark Chapman and Alan Harris, say that the disproportionate reaction to Sept. 11 has been as damaging as the destruction of lives and property on that day.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: "An objective of terrorism is to multiply damage by inducing irrational fears in the broad population," they write. "One defense is to learn to evaluate such situations more objectively." . . .

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: "Every month, including September 2001, the U.S. highway death toll exceeds fatalities in the World Trade Center, Pentagon and four downed airliners combined," they write.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
content: You Probably Think This Screed Is About You

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Matt Drudge picks up a Sunday Times of London op-ed by Norman Mailer (the Times' Sunday edition is no longer available online without a steep subscription fee) in which the author says America is "so vain":

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: Culturally, emotionally America is growing more loutish, arrogant, and vain. I detest this totally promiscuous patriotism. Wave a little flag and become a good person? Ugly. If we have a depression or fall into desperate economic times, I don't know what's going to hold the country together. . . .

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: There's just too much anger here, too much ruptured vanity, too much shock, too much identity crisis. And worst of all, too much patriotism. Patriotism in a country that's failing has a logical tendency to turn fascistic.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Bill Clinton called on the U.S. to "flush out" al Qaeda, not "flesh out," as the Associated Press quoted him. We

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span

content: The Grass Is Always Greener on the Other Side

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "U.S. politicians have expressed unhappiness with the idea of Canada in any way easing its stance on marijuana and some say if Ottawa did relax its rules, this could lead to a clampdown on the countries' long joint frontier," Reuters reports.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: "If George W. Bush becomes president, the armies of the homeless, hundreds of thousands strong, will once again be used to illustrate the opposition's arguments about welfare, the economy, and taxation."--

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: "The 'Homeless in Paradise' Inhabit Beach Cities in Growing Numbers"--headline,

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p a span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "India's first eunuch mayor has been unseated in a legal dispute over whether she is a man or a woman," the Washington Times reports:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: As all Indian eunuchs do, Kamla Jaan dresses as a woman and believes she is a female. But a judge in the central state of Madhya Pradesh ruled last week that Kamla Jaan is, in fact, a man and should be disqualified from the mayoral post, which is reserved under a quota system for a female candidate. . . .

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: Kamla Jaan, who is illiterate, argued that she was a "born eunuch"--an authentic eunuch is a castrated male--and so should not be considered a man. But in his 40-page ruling, the judge agreed with the group of petitioners that Kamla Jaan is male.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: The Times quotes P. Manorama, a physician who works with eunuchs, as saying that "roughly estimated, one in a hundred eunuchs is a natural eunuch or hermaphrodite born with deformed or ambiguous genitalia--neither a boy nor a girl." That means the other 99 are all castrated. Which leads us to wonder: Why do press reports treat this as a quaint feature of Indian culture, when it seems every bit as barbaric as the African and Muslim practice of female genital mutilation?

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: "HP Researchers Make Tiny Memory From Molecules"--headline, Reuters, Sept. 9

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Of course, lots of big things, including trucks and skyscrapers, are also made of molecules.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: A woman in Arlington, Wash., was driving her pickup truck when a red-tailed hawk collided with it. "after she freed the bird's wing from the side-view mirror, the hawk invaded the truck, bit [the woman's] lip and then sank its talons into her right arm," the Associated Press reports. She drove to a gas station and shouted: "Call 911! I have a hawk stuck to my arm."

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: The woman's name is Jamie Wing.

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p a b span
content: 'My Public Spirit Stops at My Daughter'

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: In a letter to the editor of the Washington Post, one April Falcon Doss explains why she chose to send her daughter to a private school:

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font blockquote p span
content: For a card-carrying liberal, I was surprisingly unapologetic about our decision. Why should I sacrifice our daughter's future to an abstract principle? I wasn't up to battling the school system about class size, curriculum and extracurricular activities. And by the time any changes could be made, our daughter would have already missed out on a vibrant education

tag: html body text container:page table tbody tr td container:content section:content_area font font p span
content: Here in a nutshell is the definition of an American liberal: one who is willing to sacrifice the future of
